Award.AwardTitle: RI: Small: Generation and modulation of variability in trial and error learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Reinforcement learning is a powerful learning strategy in which random perturbations are made to an output and changes that lead to more successful outputs are reinforced. Animals learn to perform highly skilled tasks by trial and error, but how biological neural networks generate variability from trial to trial is not known. An ideal model for examining this relationship between variability and learning can be found in song learning by birds. Birds learn their songs by trial and error, and are able to adjust their songs into adulthood. In addition, the basic neural architecture of the learning circuit has been mapped out; some effects of behavioral context on variability are also known. How variability is generated, and how it is controlled, can thus be studied mechanistically.

This project will study two candidate mechanisms for the generation and control of variability: chaotic dynamics in a cortex-like area, and dynamical modulation of synchrony in a basal ganglia circuit. While generic neural networks are chaotic, this project will explore how such dynamics are modified in a cortical network of biophysically plausible neurons with structured connectivity based on the known topography of the learning circuit. Furthermore, the birdsong cortical area receives inputs generated by basal ganglia. How might this input influence the variability of the output? It is proposed that the ability of activity in basal ganglia to affect cortex may depend on the synchrony of basal ganglia outputs. The studies will be constrained by experimental data from these candidate areas through collaborations with two laboratories.

The work will contribute to a general understanding of variability in biological learning, and may suggest strategies for structuring noisy input during motor learning that can lead to efficient outcomes for robotics applications. Further, Dr Fairhall is developing materials for broad outreach programs that include a Massive Online Open Course to introduce concepts in computational neuroscience to a very diverse audience, and a workshop for middle school girls interested in mathematics applied to the life sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this body of research, we were interested in how the brain produces and modulates the variations in neural activity necessary for trial and error learning. In trial and error learning, variations in a behavior are explored and good variations are reinforced while poor ones are not. In this way the behavior is improved. How are these variations generated and controlled in the brain? How are the good variations reinforced? To answer these questions, we studied how male zebra finches learn to sing. Male zebra finch learn a single mating song from adult male ‘tutors’ as young birds that they then continue to sing throughout adulthood. Regions of the basal ganglia, thalamus and a cortex-like region are part of a specialized circuit involved in learning the proper motor sequence necessary to produce song.

In our first study, we modelled a novel microcircuit within a region of the basal ganglia known to contribute to song variability. The microcircuit incorporated a new neuron type found by our collaborators. We propose a dopamine-modulated, switch mechanism that could quickly vary the firing patterns of the output of the basal ganglia, forming and dissolving synchronized cell ensembles, and thus contribute to the song variability essential for learning.

In our second study, in the context of a model of zebra finch song learning, we studied how ongoing variations in neural activity after learning is complete influence the robustness of the song system to insults such as injury or effects of aging. We found that ongoing instability in the neural representation of a stable behavior surprisingly allows a system to more readily adapt and maintain performance with minimal cost. In this framework, stereotyped behaviors are made more robust to environmental and physical change by constantly seeking subtly new ways of performing the same task.

In our third study, we considered inputs to the basal ganglia and analyzed their relationship to signaling reward and error in a natural behavior context. Male zebra finches sing a single mating song in a highly stereotyped manner; however, there are unique variations in each rendition, much the same way a person might utter a specific word slightly differently each time they say it. We analyzed how variations in song from rendition to rendition related to the activity of dopamine inputs to the basal ganglia. Our analysis shows that when zebra finches sing, dopamine inputs to the basal ganglia carry signals that resemble a moment-to-moment error: the difference between the predicted performance quality and the actual performance quality of song. This extends and connects findings in previous work that relate the role of dopamine to external rewards to a new situation where the reward is based on an internal standard of performance. Our findings suggest that circuit mechanisms used for primary rewards, such as food, may extend to more abstract notions of reward applied to subjective, internal judgements. Understanding how the brain generates and controls variations in the context of motor learning is important not only for understanding how the brain experiments, a fundamental part of any creative, complex act, but also informs understanding of pathological shifts in variation in the brain, for example in Parkinson’s disease, which is characterized by abnormal synchrony in regions of the basal ganglia and more variable movement. The neural architecture of the song system and the precision of the song behavior provide a useful framework to form a detailed, mechanistic understanding of learning and experimentation.

We strove throughout the course of this grant to communicate our ongoing findings with a broad scientific and general audience. To this end, we presented the research described above at conferences as posters, talks both for a technical and non-technical audience and as portions of communication workshops.
